keyTakeAways: A small Picasso painting, 'Still Life with Guitar' (1919), went missing during transport to a temporary exhibition in Granada, Spain.
The artwork was insured for 600,000 euros ($700,000) and was expected to be displayed from October 9, 2025, at the CajaGranada Cultural Center.
The painting vanished during the unpacking process on Monday, October 14, 2025, after being delivered and under video surveillance.
Spanish police are investigating the disappearance and have added the artwork to an international database of stolen artworks.
Picasso’s works have historically been targeted by thieves due to their high value and market demand, as evidenced by past recoveries in Greece, the Netherlands, and Belgium.
The theft occurred despite the presence of video surveillance and a secure, monitored delivery process, indicating possible insider involvement or a breach in the system.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 1919 gouache painting titled 'Still Life with Guitar' by Pablo Picasso went missing during its scheduled delivery and unpacking at the CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, Spain. The artwork, insured for 600,000 euros ($700,000), was delivered to the venue on the Friday before the exhibition, transported under video surveillance, and unpacked on Monday, October 14, 2025—when the piece was discovered to be absent. Spanish police have launched an investigation and have added the artwork to an international database of stolen artworks. The case is notable due to the historical pattern of Picasso's works being targeted by thieves, with previous recoveries in Greece, Belgium, and the Netherlands, underscoring the global threat and persistence of art theft.
